Your reason suggests that the creation of the Euro and the Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) — which brought together highly disparate national economies under a single monetary policy — was implemented without proper heed to economists. It's true that several economists had warned against rushing into a unified currency without the necessary fiscal and political union. The subsequent crises in countries like Greece and Italy validate these concerns to some extent.

However, another crucial aspect to consider is that, in many instances, economists themselves were divided on the prospects and outcomes of the Euro. Also, economic advice was not the sole criterion upon which decisions were made; political considerations played a significant role as well.

In that respect, claiming that "economists are not overrated" based solely on the Euro issue may not be comprehensive enough. Despite it all, economists play a significant role in advising governments and organizations, shaping economic policies, analyzing trends and making projections that could have massive financial implications. 

So, while I agree that economists are not overrated, I believe the rationale for this belief should go beyond issues related to the Euro.
